specialDays.name: New Year's Day
specialDays.description: Marks the beginning of the Islamic lunar calendar year.
specialDays.quote: “A new year, a new opportunity for growth and gratitude.”

todos.label: Reflect on the past year and set intentions for the new year
Offer special prayers for guidance and blessings
Recite the Du’a for the new year
Reach out and send well wishes to friends and family
Forgive and seek forgiveness

facts: The Islamic New Year marks the beginning of the new Hijri year.
It is observed on the first day of Muharram, the first month of the Islamic lunar calendar.
Muslims reflect on the Hijrah (migration) of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ from Mecca to Medina.
While not a festival, it is a time for prayer, reflection, and self-renewal.
Many Muslims make resolutions and seek forgiveness at the start of the year.

specialDays.name: Ashura
specialDays.description: Commemorates the day Prophet Musa was saved from Pharaoh. Also fasting on this day expiates sins of previous year as per hadiths.
specialDays.quote: “Ashura is a day of reflection, remembrance, and peace.”

todos.label: Fast during the day (if you wish)
Offer special prayers and supplications
Share food with friends or those in need
Give charity, even if small
Read or reflect on the story of Ashura

facts: Ashura is observed on the 10th day of Muharram, the first month of the Islamic calendar.
For Sunni Muslims, Ashura commemorates the day Prophet Moses and the Israelites were saved from Pharaoh.
For Shia Muslims, Ashura marks the martyrdom of Imam Husayn ibn Ali, the grandson of Prophet Muhammad, at Karbala.
Fasting on Ashura is highly recommended and considered to bring great reward.
Acts of kindness and charity are especially encouraged on this day.

specialDays.name: Start of Ramadan
specialDays.description: The pinnacle of Hajj; also a day of standing in prayer and seeking forgiveness.
specialDays.quote: “Ramadan is the month whose beginning is mercy, whose middle is forgiveness and whose end is freedom from fire.”

todos.label: Intend to fast and prepare spiritually
Attend Taraweeh prayers at the mosque
Wake up for suhoor (pre-dawn meal)
Make dua for blessings in this month
Begin a daily habit of reading Quran

facts: Ramadan is the ninth month of the Islamic calendar and a time of fasting, prayer, and reflection.
Fasting from dawn to sunset is obligatory for adult Muslims, except those who are ill or traveling.
The month commemorates the first revelation of the Quran to Prophet Muhammad ﷺ.
The start of Ramadan is determined by the sighting of the new moon.
Special nightly prayers called Taraweeh are performed during Ramadan.

todos.label: test

specialDays.name: Day of Arafah
specialDays.description: “There is no day on which Allah frees more people from the Fire than the Day of Arafah.”
specialDays.quote: “There is no day on which Allah frees more people from the Fire than the Day of Arafah.”

todos.label: Fast on the Day of Arafah (for non-pilgrims)
Spend extra time in prayer and supplication
Seek forgiveness and mercy from Allah
Make dua for yourself, your loved ones, and the ummah
Recite the Talbiyah and other remembrances

facts: The Day of Arafah falls on the 9th day of Dhul Hijjah, the last month of the Islamic calendar.
It is the most important day of the Hajj pilgrimage, when pilgrims stand in prayer on the Plain of Arafah.
For non-pilgrims, fasting on this day is highly recommended and expiates sins of the previous and coming year.
It is a day of supplication, forgiveness, and mercy.
The Prophet Muhammad ﷺ described it as the best day for making dua.
